Question 1: Which of the following is false with respect to lifestyle modifications for managing essential 
hypertension as recommended by AHA 2019 guidelines?
questions.explanation:
Low potassium increases blood pressure and hence is not recommended in the dietary 
modifications. On the contrary, potassium supplementation lowers the BP significantly in 
hypertensives. It is given preferably by dietary modifications unless contraindicated. 933

questions.question:
Question 2: A 57-year-old male patient presented to the clinic for a routine clinical check-up. On 
examination, his BP was found to be 136/88 mmHg. During his subsequent visits, the systolic 
blood pressure recorded was found to be within the range of 130-138 mmHg and diastolic 
blood pressure was within the range of 86-88mmHg. According to the European guidelines 
for hypertension 2018, his blood pressure would be classified as
questions.explanation:
According to European guidelines for hypertension 2018, systolic blood pressure between 130-139 
mmHg and diastolic blood pressure between 85-89 mmHg is classified as high normal.

questions.question:
Question 3: An 80-year-old male patient complains of headache and dizziness. His ambulatory BP was 
recorded to be in the range of 144-152/80-86 mmHg. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
SBP 140 mm Hg and DBP <90 mmHg is called isolated systolic hypertension. White-coat hypertension is characterized by: • The office blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg on 3 separate office visits • 2 blood pressure measurements taken outside the office are <140/90 mm Hg, frequently 
using home blood pressure monitoring; and • There is no evidence of hypertensive target organ damage.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 60-year-old male patient has grade 2 hypertension. He is also a known case of type 2 
diabetes for 9 years. What is the desired goal for blood pressure range in this patient?
questions.explanation:
In a patient (18-65 years) with hypertension and coexisting diabetes, the desired goal for systolic 
blood pressure is between 120-130 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure is between 70-79 mmHg. 
In patients above 65 years of age, the desired goal of systolic blood pressure is between 130-139 
while the desired diastolic range remains the same. This goal is in accordance with the European Society of Cardiology guidelines (2018).

questions.question:
Question 6: While treating a 45 year old hypertensive patient with underlying coronary artery disease, 
what target blood pressure should you titrate for, as per the ESC 2018 guidelines?
questions.explanation:
The target systolic blood pressure for hypertensive patients in the age group 18-65 years with 
coronary artery disease is between 120-130 mmHg.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 58-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with hypertension. On examination, there is 
no existing cardiovascular disease, no hypertension mediated organ damage (HMOD) and the 
renal function is normal. He should be immediately started with pharmacological 
management if his blood pressure is more than  
.
questions.explanation:
In this patient with no markers of cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated end-organ 
damage (HMOD), and normal renal function, immediate pharmacological treatment is 
recommended when the blood pressure (BP) is 140/90 mmHg according to the AHA and ESH on 
the management of hypertension. Guidelines for Hypertension Management: • Adults 18–79 y with SBP 140 mm Hg or DBP 90 mm Hg • Adults 80 y with SBP 160 mm Hg but 140 mm Hg can be considered. • In frail patients, individualize treatment. • In patients with CVD, especially CAD, SBP 130 mm Hg, or DBP 80 mm Hg. Treatment BP targets: • Adults 18–79 y, primary SBP/DBP goal <140/90 mm Hg; if treatment well tolerated target 
SBP/DBP <130/80 mm Hg but not SBP <120 mm Hg or DBP <70 mm Hg. For adults with 
isolated systolic hypertension, target SBP lowering, albeit cautiously. • In adults 80 y, target SBP/DBP <140/90 mm Hg, if well tolerated AHA Hypertension grading: BLOOD PRESSURE C

questions.question:
Question 8: A 72-year-old man who is a known hypertensive for 12 years comes for a regular health 
check-up. On examination, his blood pressure is 172/100 mmHg. His serum creatinine is 
1.5mg/dL, urinary albumin to creatinine ratio (UACR) is 40mg/g, and GFR is 49mL/min. 
What is the preferred antihypertensive treatment in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient is hypertensive along with chronic kidney disease. The 
preferred initial antihypertensive treatment is captopril with amlodipine. The preferred treatment in hypertensive patients with chronic kidney disease is a combination of 
angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEi) or angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) with 
calcium channel blockers (CCBs) or diuretics (ACEi/ARBs + CCBs/diuretics).

questions.question: Question 9: A hypertensive patient is on metoprolol. If verapamil is added, there is a risk of:
questions.explanation:
Metoprolol, when added with verapamil, leads to bradycardia with AV block. Verapamil and  blockers have additive effect on inhibiting SA node and AV conduction, and the 
combination should be avoided to prevent severe bradycardia and conduction block. These agents can also have additive effect on decreasing left ventricular function which could 
seriously impair cardiac output in a patient with heart failure.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 30-year-old man presents with sudden onset of a headache, palpitation, and profuse 
sweating. He had several such episodes in the past. During these episodes, his BP is found to 
be high. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.explanation:
The most likely etiology is pheochromocytoma. Patients commonly present with a classical triad 
of palpitation, headache and profuse sweating. The presence of this triad in association with 
hypertension and elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine makes pheochromocytoma a likely 
diagnosis.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 35-year-old female patient has hypokalemia, hypertension and metabolic alkalosis. What is 
the most likely etiology?
questions.explanation:
Hypertension with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis is seen in Liddle's syndrome. Liddle's syndrome (pseudo aldosteronism) is an autosomal dominant condition that is caused due 
to the increased activation of ENaC channels. This causes increased reabsorption of Na+ 
exchanged for K+ causing hypokalemia. Increased Na absorption leads to hypertension, and there 
is also a loss of H+ ion with K+, leading to metabolic alkalosis. It is associated with low renin and 
low aldosterone levels.

Question 13: Which of the following statements are true with respect to hypertensive emergency as per 
ESC 2018 guidelines?
questions.explanation:
Hypertensive emergencies are situations in which grade 3 hypertension (BP>180/110 mmHg) is 
associated with acute hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD). Treatment of hypertensive emergency depends on the type of end-organ damage present (as 
shown in the table below). It is treated with rapidly acting intravenous antihypertensive agents. In hypertensive encephalopathy, the initial goal of therapy is to immediately reduce mean arterial 
blood (MAP) pressure by no more than 25%. Rapid reduction of blood pressure may lead to 
reduced cerebral blood flow and result in cerebral infarction. 937

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following patients would you diagnose as having hypertensive urgency?
questions.explanation:
Patient 3 suffers from hypertensive urgency as BP > 180/110 mmHg and end-organ damage is 
not seen. Target organ damage is absent in hypertensive urgency but is present in a hypertensive 
emergency. Severe hypertension (grade 3) is generally defined as blood pressure 180/110 mmHg. 
Hypertensive emergency, hypertensive urgency, and malignant hypertension are all forms of 
severe hypertension. Option A: Patient 1 suffers from hypertension. Since BP <180/110 mmHg it is not a hypertensive 
crisis (urgency or emergency). Option B: Patient 2 has a BP > 180/110 mmHg along with symptoms of hypertensive 
encephalopathy. This is an example of a hypertensive emergency as there is severe hypertension 
with signs or symptoms of hypertensive-mediated organ damage (HMOD). Option D: Patient 4 has a BP > 180/110 mm Hg along with papilledema. This is a case of severe 
hypertension associated with fundoscopic changes (flame hemorrhages, papilloedema) which is 
suggestive of malignant hypertension. Microangiopathy, DIC, and encephalopathy may also be 
present. Fibrinoid necrosis of arterioles and small arteries is seen. The prognosis is very poor if 
untreated. Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) or acute hypertensive encephalopathy is a 
rare complication in patients with an acute rise in blood pressure. Due to the acute rise, there is 
increased cerebral perfusion and edema of the brain. Clinically it is recognized by alteration in 
mental status, nausea, headache, visual disturbance, seizure, or development of focal neurological 
deficits. 938 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: A 55-year-old female patient who is a known case of hypertension, diabetes, and 
hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and vomiting. 
The patient is agitated and her blood pressure is 220/120 mmHg. Ophthalmoscopy reveals 
the presence of papilledema. Which of the following antihypertensive is least useful in the 
management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
The above scenario points towards the diagnosis of malignant hypertension. The drug which is 
least useful in the management is furosemide(diuretic). Volume depletion is common in patients with malignant hypertension, and the administration of 
a diuretic together with a hypertensive agent can lead to an extreme drop in blood pressure. Diuretics are generally not recommended for the rapid reduction of blood pressure in patients 
with hypertensive crises. They are used only in conditions of volume overload such as acute 
pulmonary edema.

Question 16: 932 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is the most important risk factor for the development of 
hypertension?
questions.explanation:
The most important risk factor for the development of hypertension is obesity. Hypertension is defined as repeated office systolic blood pressure of  140 mm Hg and/or diastolic 
blood pressure of  90 mm Hg. Primary/essential hypertension is the leading cause of hypertension in adults. It is caused due to 
the interaction of genetic factors with various other factors such as diet, sedentary lifestyle, etc. In 
some people, hypertension may result from renal, endocrine, or adrenal disorders (secondary 
hypertension). Risk factors of hypertension can be divided into modifiable and non-modifiable: Non-modifiable risk factors are: • Age- risk increases with age • Sex- in young and middle-aged adults, the risk is higher in males • Genetic factors- mutation in the genes which encode the components of the 
renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, atrial natriuretic peptide, and alpha adducin • Ethnicity Modifiable risk factors are: • Obesity (most important) • High alcohol intake • High salt intake • Sedentary lifestyle • Stress • Dyslipidemia • Diet low in potassium and calcium 939
